docs.lead_paragraph: Lauren Slater is a self-professed liar. But this time she really wants you to believe her. Ms. Slater, a 36-year-old psychologist in Boston, is the author of the recently released ''Lying: A Metaphorical Memoir.'' The book is billed as a memoir but is actually a blending of fact and fiction, in which the main character, Ms. Slater, thinks she has epilepsy but may be imagining her condition.

headline.main: Media Talk; Questionable Letter For a Liar's Memoir

docs.abstract: Lauren Slater, author of Lying: A Metaphorical Memoir, sends letter to New York Times Book Review purporting to be from the philosophy professor who wrote book's introduction and who wanted to rebut assertion by Rebecca Mead, who reviewed book, that he did not exist; says that her editors knew professor was fiction and that letter was intended to be funny; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Home Town, by Tracy Kidder. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $14.95.) Through personal profiles and historical and demographic digressions, the author takes the pulse of Northampton, Mass., a city of 30,000 highly diverse people. Most of the natives leave when they reach adulthood, and are replaced by newcomers. Kidder's ''smart and gently ironic writing is always good company,'' Ben Yagoda wrote here in 1999. Louse, by David Grand. (Harvest/Harcourt, $13.) This satirical tale of a monstrous tycoon modeled on the aging Howard Hughes and the loyal valet who tends to his boss's increasingly eccentric demands mirrors the plight of workers in an era of job insecurity and corporate brainwashing. The result is ''a delightfully eerie and angry first novel,'' David Sacks said here last year.
